newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan high-techs encouraged by Nasdaq rally.
newsitem.headline: Japan high-techs encouraged by Nasdaq rally.

text.p: Shares in Japan's high technology sector strengthened in morning trade on Wednesday, heartened by the overnight rally by high techs in New York, brokers said.
Fujitsu Ltd added 10 yen to stand at 1,390. Fujitsu was the fourth most heavily traded issue on the Tokyo bourse with 2.57 million shares traded by midday.
Tokyo Electron Ltd hit a high for the calendar year before retracing to 5,150 yen, up 100.
"The outlook for the firm's business is not exceptionally strong, but investors think there is room for growth as the outlook for chip makers is improving," a broker at a medium-sized brokerage said.
NEC Corp also rose, adding 20 yen to 1,610.

"The jump in Nasdaq came at a time when trade in incentive-backed issues, which had been supporting the market in recent sessions was beginning to wane in Tokyo," said Harushige Kobayashi, deputy general manager at Yamaichi Securities.
On Tuesday, the Nasdaq finished up 19, or 1.4 percent, at 1,409, crossing the 1,400 threshold for the first time.
Brokers added that investors were also steered to high-tech issues due to healthy earnings forecasts for some of the firms announced recently.
One such share was Pioneer Electronic Corp, which gained 140 to 2,720 yen at midday, a new high for the calendar year.

"Until now, the shares were considered to be a loser," a "Big Four" broker said. "However, the firm is expected to come back into black in the year ended March 1998 and investors are appreciating the forecast."
Pioneer said last week that it expected a parent current profit of 4.8 billion yen in fiscal 1997/98, compared to a loss of 4.10 billion yen the previous year.
